Award.AwardTitle: Structural Biology of Tetrahymena Telomerase Interactions at Telomeres

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Telomerase is a special enzyme composed of proteins and RNA that maintains the DNA at the very ends of our chromosomes, called telomeres. Telomerase is a highly regulated determinant of stem cell renewal, aging, and tumorigenesis. In this research project, the PI will investigate the structure and function of proteins that interact with telomerase and telomeres. The project will use telomerase and telomere binding proteins from the model organism Tetrahymena, a ciliated protozoan, which has previously led to basic discoveries. This project will provide essential training for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in structural biology and biophysics and help them become the next generation of leaders in this multidisciplinary field. This project will also train women, minority, and economically disadvantaged high school, undergraduate, and graduate students to pursue careers in science.

Telomerase is an RNA-protein complex (RNP) that extends the 3â€™ ends of linear chromosomes by repetitively synthesizing the short telomere repeat sequence (TTGGGG in ciliates) using an RNA template embedded in its telomerase RNA (TER) and its specialized telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT). Telomerase activity at telomeres counteracts the loss of DNA that would otherwise occur during each round of replication. Telomerase is recruited to telomeres and activated by telomere end protection proteins, which otherwise serve to protect telomere ends from being detected as double strand breaks by the DNA damage response. This project will use NMR spectroscopy, X-ray crystallography, cryo electron microscopy (cryoEM), and biochemical methods to investigate the structures and interactions of Tetrahymena telomerase 741 and TEB with p50 and with telomere end-protection proteins, to elucidate their roles in telomeric DNA synthesis, regulation, and end protection. This project is supported by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster of the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division in the Directorate for Biological Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Telomerase is an RNA-protein complex (RNP) that extends the 3’-ends of linear chromosomes by repetitively synthesizing the short telomere repeat sequence (TTGGGG in ciliates and TTAGGG in humans) using an RNA template that is part of its essential telomerase RNA (TER) component and its specialized telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT). Telomerase activity is tightly regulated during development and oncogenesis. In humans, telomerase insufficiency in stem and germline cells due to mutations in telomerase components is manifested as diseases including dyskeratosis congenita, aplastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndromes, and pulmonary fibrosis, while mutations that upregulate the TERT promoter are the most common noncoding mutations in cancer. The Feigon laboratory has pioneered structural biology studies of telomerase from the model organism Tetrahymena thermophila, a ciliated protozoan where telomerase was first discovered. Tetrahymena telomerase comprises, in addition to the catalytic core of TERT and TER, an assembly protein p65 plus several proteins initially thought to be unique to ciliate telomerase. We discovered that these accessory proteins are apparently orthologues of human telomere end-binding or associated proteins that only transiently interact with human telomerase. These include p50 and Teb1, that in humans activates telomerase (TPP1) and binds the G-strand (POT1), respectively, together recruiting telomerase to telomere ends; and p75–p45–p19 that in humans is CTC1–STN1–TEN1 (CST), a replication protein A (RPA) related complex that recruits DNA Polymerasea-Primase to inhibit G-strand synthesis and synthesize the complementary C-strand. Tetrahymena telomerase is thus an ideal model system for understanding activation of telomerase for G-strand synthesis, recruitment to telomeres, and the role of CST in C-strand synthesis. During the course of this grant we have used NMR spectroscopy and cryo-electron microscopy (cryoEM) along with rigorous biochemistry to investigate the structures, interactions, and functions of these accessory proteins. We have outstanding achievements during this grant, published in 3 Nature papers, plus PNAS, RNA Biology, JMB, and a Curr Opin Struct Biol review, that have defined the structures, interactions, and functions of Tetrahymena telomerase accessory proteins. Our primary accomplishments on this grant are:  (1) We determined a cryoEM structure of Tetrahymena telomerase at 3.3 Å overall resolution for the catalytic core RNP (TERT–TER–p65), p50, and TEB. This allowed us for the first time to accurately model p50, which revealed its structural homology to human TPP1 and suggested that p50 and TPP1 interact with the same regions of TERT; (2) Using focused refinement and combined data sets, we determined the structure of the dynamic Tetrahymena telomerase p75–p45–p19 complex (Tt CST), and validated its structural homology to human CST. (3) We determined how p75 (Ctc1) interacts with p50, by combining information from cryoEM and NMR spectroscopy. (4) We assembled and determined the structure of a Tetrahymena telomerase–Polymerasea-Primase complex, which showed that it interacts with Tetrahymena CST for C-strand synthesis; (5) We determined the structure of human telomerase with TPP1, which allowed us to directly compare the structures of p50 and TPP1 and their interactions with TERT, confirming our previous models and providing new insights; (6) p65–TER interaction is important for assembly of the complex with TERT. However, in cryoEM structures of telomerase, only part of the structure of p65 has high enough resolution for the full-length protein in complex with TER to be determined. Combining cryoEM, NMR spectroscopy, and Rosetta modeling we determined the structure of this LARP7 family protein, which revealed previously unknown structural motifs and interactions essential for function.

Broader impacts Twenty years after my laboratory initiated NSF funded studies of telomerase, using NMR spectroscopy on telomerase RNA and protein domains, we have now solved cryoEM structures of Tetrahymena telomerase and complexes that have provided mechanistic and functional insights into G-strand synthesis by telomerase and complementary C-strand synthesis by CST–PolaPrim. This body of work has broad impact on our understanding of equivalent activities and interactions of human telomerase and therefore on human health and disease. Our lab almost uniquely integrates information from solution NMR spectroscopy with cryoEM, providing insights that could not be obtained with either method alone, as we illustrated for p50–Ctc1 and p65–TER in telomerase. The training provided in my laboratory under this award has helped prepare postdocs for careers in academic science and biotechnology, with currently two assistant professors in academia, one at an RNA biotechnology company, and two on the academic job market. Six female undergraduates have done research in the laboratory during this project period, including one woman of color and one first generation Mexican-American. Of these, three are co-authors on laboratory publications. Of the 5 that have graduated, four are in graduate school and one is a research technician in my laboratory.  My laboratory participates annually in UCLA PEERS (Program for Excellence in Education and Research in the Sciences) for disadvantaged undergraduate science majors and in UCLA Undergraduate Research Poster Day (undergraduate presenters and postdoc poster judges).
